posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
I’m trying to put together autonomous code using a command based structure.

I have an autonomous command that raises my arm to specified encoder value using PID.

I would like to raise the arm, then drive forward, lower the arm, and then drive backward.

The problem is that as soon as I reach the set height and move to the next command (ie. the drive forward), the motor releases and the arm drops back down. I want it to reach that position and hold the position.

I’ve tried setting it up first raising it into position and then using a ParallelCommandGroup  of both the arm raise and drivetrain, but I still have the same problem - as soon as it starts moving forward the arm drops because it’s already at the encoder height.

I’m guessing it has something to do with isFinished, but I’m not able to wrap my head around it. Here is the code for my isFinished:

@Override public boolean isFinished() { if ((Math.abs(setpoint - armPivotSubsystem.getEncoderMeters())) < 0.4) { System.out.println(“AutoPivot complete”); return true; } else { return false; } }

The entire code is here if that helps: GitHub - MrCauthers/2023MainWindsor

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
Hiya! I would suggest putting the PID inside of the subsystem itself, then set the position you need to go to with the command. That way, the subsystem actively fights to remain at that position until you reset the position with a different command.

Some resources on that can be found here: PIDController API Docs ArmFeedForwards

Feel free to ask if you have any further questions, comments, concerns, or Haikus!

link_counts.title: Feedforward Control in WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
Your issue is your using the PID to calculate the motor speed.  Then when your command ends, you set the motor speed to 0, which is why it doesn’t hold in place.

Do you have an encoder on the arm you’re pivoting?  A much better solution to this problem would be to use Positional control.  Your code references CANSparkMax motor controllers.  If you have an encoder wired to it, you can follow their code examples to use positional PIDs to set your arm to the desired location.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
They actually aren’t setting the speed. Due to poor word choice, it’s confusing. They are actually setting the power of the motor using positional control.

(I blame poor documentation on the vendor’s end)

For more context: Rev’s documentation says the for CANSparkMax objects, .set()  is a “Common interface for setting the speed of a speed controller.” However, this is incorrect. It’s actually a scale of power output from the motor. Thus: using the set function to set the “speed” of the motor to 0 doesn’t actually 0 the speed, it just cause the motor to not apply voltage. This is fine if no other force is acting against your mechanism. Unfortunately, anti-gravity has not been invented yet, so we have to deal with that pesky natural force that keeps pulling us down. Setting your speed to 0 wouldn’t stop it from slowly moving down.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
Yeah, that’s what I was saying, by not using the built-in position control there’s nothing holding it in place (save maybe the gear ratio).

If there’s an encoder attached, instead of called “set” they could call “setReference” on the motor controller’s PID controller and that should hold it in place (I think).  We don’t use spark max’s, so I’m not as familiar with them as I am with CTRE controllers.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the responses.

It took me all of about 30 seconds to determine I have a 0% chance of understanding anything in that feedforward section. I was really hoping this would have a simple solution, but it looks like I’m just going to have to let it go. We’re hopping on a bus to head to Windsor for the competition this weekend, and I’m not going to learn advanced engineering in an hour, sadly. And moving all of the PID at this point would probably cause catastrophic failure to everything else in place, so I’ll have to try to figure something else out.

I took a look at the code examples for positional PID, but again it’s way over my head. I have no idea where most of the numbers are coming from in it. And I’m guessing I’d have to be able to figure that out before trying to use this, so again I’ll have to just let it go.

I do appreciate the help though. Unfortunately I just ran out of time to try to get everything done.

posts.name: David Lame
posts.cooked:
MrCauthers:

…I’m not going to learn advanced engineering in an hour, sadly. And moving all of the PID at this point would probably cause catastrophic failure to everything else in place, so I’ll have to try to figure something else out.

I took a look at the code examples for positional PID , but again it’s way over my head. I have no idea where most of the numbers are coming from in it.

That’s probably true, about the catastrophic failure.  You could end up applying 100% power, or -100% power, at a time when that would be a very bad idea, and you might break something.

Despite that, I’ll talk a little about “where those numbers are coming from”.

My first encounter with PID was as a graduate student taking a control systems class.  The professor explained how the differential equations describing the system being controlled, which we called “the plant”, in the case of FIRST , it’s the arm, would interract with the differential equations of the PID feedback loop, and you could then set the coefficients for KP, KI, and KD to make sure the system was stable, and then optimize overshoots and rise times.

Which was all true, and mostly useless, because you never had the equations of the plant.  Real engineers sometimes spend weeks, or maybe months or longer depending on the system, getting that so they can use it.  However, the more common case, used by even more real engineers on simpler systems, is to wing it.  And that’s what I do in FIRST , and that’s what I teach my students.  The college stuff with the differential equations is the better way to do it, but you might not have the time or money to do that, but winging it still works most of the time.

Suppose you decide that you want to move your arm.  Based on your arm and how you move the joysticks under manual control, you decide that when you are 45 degrees away from your setpoint, you should move it at 50% power.  Your encoder has been translated into degrees.

In that case, when you are 45 degrees away, the output will be KP*45, and you want that to be 0.5.

Kp*45=0.5.  Solve for Kp.

Will that work?  No, but it will put you on the right track.  In some systems, like rotational control in the floor plane, that will actually often work.  That’s basically what I usually do for robot spin control, and it works fine.  On arms, though, there’s gravity.

Just because people don’t like reading hastily written, and therefore inexact, descriptions, I won’t go into more details, but if you use that for an arm, the arm will get stuck part of the way up.  Basically, the problem is that the output is equal to KP* error.  When you get to where you are going, error is zero, so the motors turn off.  In practice, there’s a point on the way up where kP*error is just enough to hold it at a steady position, but not the position you want.

You need a non-zero term.  That can be the KI term, or the FF term.  If there’s interest, I’ll describe those later, although my hope is that someone has already done a nice writeup of these things, without the differential equations part, and they see my post and say, “Don’t listen to that guy!  Read this white paper.”  and they provide a link.  I just don’t know of any white paper that describes it in terms a person can understand without doing all the math.

They’ll teach you the math in college, and depending on your job, you might even use it later.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
David_Lame:

Which was all true, and mostly useless, because you never had the equations of the plant. Real engineers sometimes spend weeks, or maybe months or longer depending on the system, getting that so they can use it. However, the more common case, used by even more real engineers on simpler systems, is to wing it. And that’s what I do in FIRST, and that’s what I teach my students. The college stuff with the differential equations is the better way to do it, but you might not have the time or money to do that, but winging it still works most of the time.

The plant equation for a simple DC motor is not all that complicated, and definitely doesn’t require weeks or months to understand.  Most FRC mechanisms are pretty well-approximated by an ideal DC motor under some simple loading scheme.

David_Lame:

although my hope is that someone has already done a nice writeup of these things, without the differential equations part, and they see my post and say, “Don’t listen to that guy! Read this white paper.” and they provide a link. I just don’t know of any white paper that describes it in terms a person can understand without doing all the math.

This page explains the conceptual and mathematical workings of WPILib’s SimpleMotorFeedforward (and the other related classes). The Permanent-Magnet DC Motor Feedforward Equation: Recall from earli...

The article also links to tooling that can help you calculate gains for your mechanism.  Subsequent articles include simulations that demonstrate what each gain means and how they interact while tuning.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: David Lame
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

The plant equation for a simple DC motor is not all that complicated, and definitely doesn’t require weeks or months to understand.

I think you are underestimating the quality of your education.  If that doesn’t take you long to understand, it’s because you’ve seen lots of equations that are kinds of similar, and done a lot of homework problems.

I’m trying to use a language that high school students have some hope of understanding, without the aid of an expert mentor.  Given the description of what MrCauthers did and did not understand, I don’t think he’s going to understand the paper that you linked.

Fortunately, it isn’t necessary.  I can tell you I made an arm that held its position sufficiently accurately in autonomous to place a cone on a peg without using anything at all about the DC motor equation.  I’ve taught students in the past to do rotation control and elevator code using PID control, without them needing to understand why there are two dots above the d at the end of that DC motor equation…and without having to know that there is such a thing as the DC motor equation.

Students:  Don’t get me wrong.  Understanding those equations is critical to effective control systems design.  Understanding it would be a great off season project, especially using the tools that are linked in the article.  Very valuable.  On the other hand, if the bus is leaving tomorrow, knowing what speed you want, and that if you use the I term to get past the place where it sticks,  can probably get you into the playoff round.

In my professional experience, knowing the differential equations can get you a job.  Knowing how to “wing it”, will make you more capable of doing the job.  Being able to relate the two of those things makes you a very valuable employee, and will let you live in a bigger house.
